Pursuant to the Resolution of the House of Representatives passed on 31 May 1985, the House of Representatives met on Tuesday, 20 August 1985, at 2 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF MR JOHN ARMSTRONG ENGLAND, ED

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House expresses its deep regret at the death of Mr John Armstrong England, CMG, ED, a former Member for the Division of Calare, who died on 18 June 1985, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to his wife and family.

John England was born in October 1911 in Brisbane and educated at Brisbane Boys College. At the age of 20 he commenced what was to be a long and distinguished career in the Australian defence forces by joining the Australian Garrison Artillery and later the Australian Light Horse. With the outbreak of war he transferred to the 2nd Australian Imperial Force and served with distinction in what was then West New Guinea, Morotai, Labuan and Sarawak. He was promoted to lieutenant-colonel in 1943 and was mentioned in dispatches. After the war he remained as a Reserve officer until 1962.

John England was elected as the member for Calare in November 1960. He served in this House for 15 years until his retirement in 1975 and, as well as serving on a number of parliamentary committees, he held the position of Whip in his Party from 1972 until his retirement. He was a man who worked hard for what he believed and who served his electorate and his country well. On behalf of members of the Government, I extend to his widow and to his family our sympathy and our regret at his passing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). John England was a very fine Australian. His service to the nation covered both war and peace, and a broad spectrum of service it was. The Prime Minister has mentioned his service with the Citizen Military Forces before the Second World War, his service during the war in the 2nd Australian Imperial Force, his service to this Parliament, and his service to the Northern Territory as its Administrator during a vital time in the Territory's history. Later, of course, he was Secretary to the Federal Council of the National Party of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In John England we had a warm, personal human being who served in this Parliament. He evoked a great spirit of friendliness. His courage and his ability, together with that friendliness and courtesy, are I think a summation of the finest qualities in a lifetime of service in war and peace. He was a family man who found fulfilment in politics and soldiering and also even in the gentler pursuits of music and gardening. Those of us who worked with him for so long admired him greatly, and we extend our sympathy to his wife and to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

Over the years in which he served this Parliament he occupied many positions. DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF MR FREDERICK RONALD BIRRELL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses its deep regret at the death of Mr Frederick Ronald Birrell, a former Member for the Division of Port Adelaide who died on 23 July 1985, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders profound sympathy to his wife and family.

Fred Birrell was born at Parkside in Adelaide in December 1913. He was educated at Adelaide Boys High School. As a young man he had a vigorous life. He distinguished himself on the sportsfield as a member of the 1934 Glenelg premiership team and worked hard in his local community.

Fred Birrell joined the Australian Labor Party in the early 1930s and remained its loyal supporter all his life. He gave service to the Labor movement also as a trade union official for the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia for nearly 20 years. In 1940, he enlisted with the Royal Australian Air Force and served his country with pride throughout the war before being discharged in 1946 with the rank of sergeant.

Fred Birrell was elected to Parliament in 1963 as the member for Port Adelaide and served in this place for 11 years. During that time he served his electorate diligently and never forgot the interests of the ordinary working men and women he represented. He was well known for the considerable efforts he made on behalf of individual constituents with problems. Fred Birrell had, in addition, a fine record of community service in Adelaide. He was the first Secretary to the Findon High School Council and was a foundation member of the Seaton North Progress Association. Fred Birrell was a loyal and hard-working member of the Australian Labor Party who served both his country and this Parliament well. Mr Speaker, on behalf of the Government I extend to his widow Patricia and to his three children, Pamela, Julie and Ronald, sincerest sympathy and regret at the loss of a fine Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I support the motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I also served in this Parliament with Fred Birrell. The Prime Minister has spoken of Fred Birrell's background, his service to the union movement and his service to the Australian Labor Party. He played a part in a real and active sense in the birth and growth of one of Australia's most important industries. For just over a decade he deeply involved himself in matters in this Parliament, but beyond the Parliament itself I recall his service in international parliamentary affairs. He served in the broader bipartisan elements of parliamentary democracy as we know it. He was a member, councillor and then deputy leader of three delegations to Inter-Parliamentary Union meetings between 1969 and 1972.

SPEECH.PARA: Fred Birrell appeared to me to be a shy man. I was a much younger man when I first became a member of this Parliament, naturally enough, but I remember Fred. There seemed to me to be behind that shyness, however, a strong willed and determined personality and a man of the highest moral principles and standards. On behalf of the Opposition, I extend deepest sympathy to his wife and his children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the members of the National Party of Australia, I join in the motion of condolence moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and supported by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF DAME DOROTHY TANGNEY, DBE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses its deep regret at the death of Dame Dorothy Margaret Tangney, DBE, who died on 1 June 1985, and places on record its appreciation of her long and meritorious public service

Dorothy Tangney was born in 1911, the third child in a family of nine children. Her father was an engine driver and the family was very poor. During her early years Dorothy lived in the mill towns of Mayanup and Holyoake. The family then moved to Fremantle. Here, Dorothy won a State secondary scholarship, which paid for her attendance at St Joseph's Convent for five years secondary schooling. On matriculation, like other young women, she used the monitor system, combining school teaching and part time study, to complete a Bachelor of Arts degree at the University of Western Australia. She continued, as a post-graduate student, to take out a Diploma of Education. At university she was active on student committees, notably the debating society and the University Labor Club, and became the first woman president of the Societies Council of the Guild of Undergraduates, an achievement recognised by the award of honorary life associateship of the Guild. She was the first woman to be so honoured.

She began teaching in the heart of the Fremantle industrial area, where she witnessed daily the effects of depressed shipping conditions on the families of waterfront workers. She saw there the full effects of the Depression-malnutrition among children, young people forced to leave school early to look for some job in an often vain attempt to contribute to the family income, and families broken up by hardship and despair. This experience had a profound effect in shaping her beliefs and in hardening her resolve to work for better conditions for working men and women in Australia.

Dorothy Tangney was naturally drawn to politics. An active member of the Australian Labor Party, she contested a State parliamentary seat in 1936 and 1939, and was placed on the Federal Senate ticket in 1940 and 1943. Although she was in fourth position, Mr Speaker-a position from which one would normally not expect to be elected-a voting landslide saw all four ALP candidates elected in 1943. As a result, she was the first woman to take a seat in the Australian Senate. Until 1967, she headed the ALP Western Australian nominations for the Senate ticket. Again, she was the first woman to do so for a major party.

As the first woman senator, she bore an enormous responsibility. Many did not believe that a woman could succeed in the traditionally male area of parliament; nevertheless, her success was outstanding. On Dorothy Tangney's retirement one of her colleagues said that it was a tribute to the success with which she carried out her duties as a senator that other parties said:
If women can do as splendid a job as Dorothy Tangney we had better also be represented by women in the Senate.
Another colleague, Dame Ivy Wedgwood, said:
She provided a bridge over which other women have been able to become members of this House.

Dorothy Tangney's central political interests were driven by her early experiences in Fremantle during the Depression years. She was a strong advocate of governments taking responsibility for adequate social services. She championed Commonwealth assistance for schools and greater recognition of the position of deserted wives, civilian widows and war widows. Remembering the terrible cost of the effects of tuberculosis amongst the children of the Depression, she also strongly supported the campaign to eradicate tuberculosis-the great white death of the time. On her retirement, she referred with great pleasure to the introduction of the medical and pharm- aceutical benefits scheme and the free hospitalisation scheme, which were other long-standing personal concerns.

Between 1943 and 1946, Dorothy Tangney was a member of the Joint Committee on Social Security, established by the Curtin Labor Government in 1943. She considered that some of her most valuable work was accomplished through serving on that Committee. By the time she left Parliament, the Committee's recommendations on such matters as child endowment and hospital benefits had all become law. In her period in Parliament, she made a substantial contribution to what she considered to be the revolution in the attitudes of politicians towards those social welfare reforms.

A notable contribution outside the Parliament was Dorothy Tangney's membership of the Council of the Australian National University from 1951 until her retirement. She saw it grow from a collection of wooden huts in a paddock, as it was described in its early days, to an establishment with a world-wide reputation for scholarship and research. Again, she was the first and only woman member of that Council for many years.
In 1967, Dorothy Tangney was created a Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire. She accepted the award in these terms:

I have accepted it upon my own responsibility because I think it is a step in the right direction. Women who are members of my party have not always had the recognition to which I think they have been entitled. In accepting this honour I think I have opened the door for them in years to come.
Her parliamentary achievements were recognised also when in 1974 the new Federal seat in Western Australia was named Tangney.

Dorothy Tangney retired from active politics in 1968. Colleagues from all parties praised her hard work, her sense of humour and wit, and her very considerable achievements as the first woman senator. I had the pleasure and the privilege of knowing Dorothy Tangney personally and of counting her as a friend. She was a remarkable Australian and her place in Australian history is firmly established. Her achievements in her time were the greater because she was a woman. The country, this Parliament and the party to which I belong have lost a great citizen. On behalf of the Government I wish to record our profound regret and sadness at the passing of this great Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the motion he has moved. He is indeed correct in describing Dame Dorothy Tangney as a remarkable Australian. As he has recounted, she was elected to the Senate for Western Australia in the general election of 1943, and she served in that chamber for nearly a quarter of a century. Those of us who were here at the time recall only too well that she left reluctantly. As she said in her valedictory address to her fellow senators after her defeat in the 1967 election:

SPEECH.PARA: I am very sorry to be leaving the Senate . . . I am not doing so voluntarily. I had hoped to be able to complete some of the tasks which I had set myself.

I believe that statement was typical of Dame Dorothy Tangney, Australia's first woman senator. It exemplified both her frankness and quiet modesty. I say her quiet modesty, because she could have been forgiven for believing that the tasks she had accomplished were more than sufficient for one person. She was a tireless worker, both inside and outside the Parliament. Over nearly 25 years she served on innumerable committees and as a member of many important overseas delegations. The Prime Minister quoted a statement of Dame Ivy Wedgwood, who was a close and dear friend of my grandmother and was of great assistance to me when I first came into this Parliament. I know that the words the Prime Minister quoted from Dame Ivy could have been broadened to a considerable extent, such was the admiration that one of the pioneer women on our side of politics had for Dame Dorothy Tangney.

As I said, Dame Dorothy Tangney was a tireless worker, both inside and outside the Parliament. Her chief interests were social welfare and the creation of new rights and opportunities for women. In these as in so many other areas of her public life, she was literally years before her time. Her vigorous arguments that the Federal Government had a financial responsibility to the unemployed, the sick and the infirm helped to create the social welfare policies that have been implemented by successive Federal governments. Similarly, in education she was a pioneer. The Prime Minister has described correctly and graphically her work as a foundation member and the only woman member of the Council of the Australian National University from 1951 to 1968, helping it to grow, as he said, in effect, from a run-down collection of army huts to an institution of the highest international standard. She knew the value of education. The daughter of an engine driver, she won her own education through scholarships, which led her to a teaching career for which she studied at night, after working by day to help support her eight brothers and sisters.

The courage, determination and sense of humour which sustained her throughout the years of high endeavour were shown clearly when in 1967 she had only a slim chance of re-election, given her place on the Australian Labor Party Senate ticket. She said: `I have got my Irish up and I am going to fight like mad'. After her defeat, she said: `Well, you might lose everything else but you cannot lose your sense of humour. This was displayed amply in her valedictory speech. Her determination to provide a better, more secure and more fruitful life for all Australians is an example to us all. It is a tragedy that these feelings come out too infrequently-usually on the occasion of the death of such a person-but she, in many ways, epitomises the great contributor to Australian politics. It matters not one whit on which side of the Parliament one sat, the fact remains that Dorothy Tangney was a remarkable Australian, as the Prime Minister said. The Opposition joins him, with a great deal of sorrow, in expressing condolences to her family. We remember her for her tolerance, graciousness and sense of humour which were displayed so abundantly in a long and very distinguished career in this Parliament.

She was the first woman to hold office on the Executive of the parliamentary Labor Party and the first woman to represent Australia at the British Empire Parliamentary Association Conference in 1948. She was also the first woman to sit on the Council of the Australian National University. But she was principally known as a champion of the underdog, and there is little doubt that her contribution in arguing for the needy contributed to the implementation of policies under Prime Minister John Curtin which first saw the Commonwealth bear legislative responsibility for providing help for the unemployed and the infirm.

Certainly, she had a great sense of humour. I can well remember that those of us who stayed in the old Kurrajong Hotel on many occasions made her the butt of attempts to draw her into participating in various affairs that she would have preferred not to be part of. Indeed, my colleague the former member for Darling Downs, Ceb Barnes, whom some members of this House will remember, was lured into her boudoir one night as a result of a purported invitation from some other members of the Parliament, much to the frustration of both parties. She was a remarkable lady and one who made an enormous contribution in so many ways. Those of us who recall her can do so with pride. She was a remarkable Australian and her example could be followed advantageously by many people in this world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) in their remarks about Dorothy Tangney. Dorothy Tangney was elected on the same day as Fred Daly and I know that she was deeply touched when Fred rang her in 1974 and suggested that one of the two new seats that had been created as a result of the redistributions in Western Australia and the Australian Capital Territory should be named after her. Of course, Fred had wanted a much larger redistribution and he only had the opportunity to name those two seats. Interestingly, the commissioners who in those days were responsible for recommending names, but not in fact naming electorates, had proposed that the electorate that became Tangney be called O'Connor. Had this been an opportunity for making controversial observations, I might have noted how differently that name of O'Connor might have been brought into this House. The name of O'Connor, of course, comes from my great grandfather. It was therefore with somewhat mixed feelings that I heard the news that Fred had decided to recommend to this House, and that this House had agreed, that the name O'Connor should be replaced by the name Tangney. It was only then that I got to know Dame Dorothy Tangney, because shortly thereafter I was pre-selected as the Australian Labor Party's candidate to contest the seat of Tangney, which I later won.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a mild controversy during that elect-ion campaign in that both I and the candidate for the Liberal Party ended up being publicly associated with Dame Dorothy, or at least having Dame Dorothy publicly associated with us-I because of the Labor Party association and the Liberal candidate because his mother had apparently been taught by Dame Dorothy. I think Dame Dorothy was, to some extent, distraught by this confusion and I must say it was a matter of great attention at the time. But when we look back on it I think we realise that many people were delighted, and in fact wanted, to be associated with the great contribution that Dorothy Tangney had made to politics and indeed in representing Western Australia in Canberra.

She spent most of her time in opposition and her frustration must have been considerable. I think everybody knows how difficult the role of an Opposition member or senator is, yet she never spared herself in trying to do whatever she could to bring about the changes which she sought in society. I think she was able to observe at the time of her retirement that so many of the goals for which she had fought had in fact been accomplished. I think that was a matter of great comfort to her.

She travelled between Canberra and Perth at a time when travel arrangements were fairly prehistoric. She detested the aeroplanes which then traversed the continent, landing several times between here and there, and preferred to travel by train and sometimes by boat. As a result she was not seen in Western Australia as frequently as she would have liked, although she was probably seen there more frequently than I am these days. Notwithstanding her long absences from Western Australia, she was very much loved by the Western Australian community. I am sure that is the reason why she continued to represent Western Australia in the Senate for such a long time.

I think Fred Daly's proposal that that electorate in Western Australia be named after Dorothy Tangney was a great proposal. Until the last election it had always been held by a Government member, but as a result of the redistribution it is now held and, I suppose, for the forseeable future will be held by an Opposition member. Notwithstanding that, it does mean that the name of a very great politician and a very great Western Australian will always be represented in this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the previous speakers in supporting this condolence motion for Senator Dame Dorothy Margaret Tangney. As the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) stated, it is a rare privilege to be able to meet the person after whom one's Federal seat is named, and it is a privilege that I share with the Minister and the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear).

SPEECH.PARA: I first contested the seat of Tangney in 1977. After winning that seat I took it upon myself to meet Dame Dorothy Tangney. When I visited her she was living in retirement in her family home in Claremont. On several occasions in the late 1970s I visited her until old age forced her into a local nursing home and, sadly, affected her ability to converse. During my visits Dame Dorothy took great pleasure in recounting stories of the Parliament as she knew it in the late 1940s, 1950s and into the 1960s. As the Minister for Trade has stated, it was not uncommon then for senators and members from Western Australia, instead of madly commuting weekly as we do nowadays, to travel to Canberra by train, plane or, as in Dame Dorothy's case, boat and then stay for the entire three-month sitting of Parliament before returning to their electorates in their home States. This style of parliamentary life-and I have heard other members and senators speak of it-created a much closer atmosphere and environment, and friendships naturally flourished more easily across party lines. Weekend Parliament House tennis parties were a great favourite of Dame Dorothy, and she enjoyed recalling those times and the many friends she made. This ability to mix readily with people on all sides of politics and from all walks of life was a hallmark of Dame Dorothy's career.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has rightly and adequately outlined the hallmarks of her career. Let me simply reinforce that by saying that her decision to enter parliament stemmed from her realisation that this was a logical place in which to work for improved living standards for those in greatest need and for Australia as a whole. As we know, with her election to the Senate, Dame Dorothy became Australia's first woman senator. Again, as the Prime Minister has outlined, she went on to record a number of firsts which cannot be beaten. In a Senate career which has spanned a few weeks short of 25 years, a career throughout which, I might mention, she was ably assisted by her sister, Phyllis Smith, who acted as her secretary, Dame Dorothy worked consistently to achieve improved social welfare. She spent all but six of her years in the Senate in Opposition, but her vigorous campaigning and assiduous committee work produced a long list of benefits for the disadvantaged. Her tireless efforts helped to win Federal Government acknowledgement of its financial responsibility for the unemployed and the infirm. As the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) has said, she was a consistent champion of the underdog.

At the end of her long parliamentary career Dame Dorothy was deservedly created a Dame of the British Empire, and her distinguished contribution to public life has also given her the equally rare honour of having her portrait hung in King's Hall along with those of Prime Ministers and other great Australian leaders. Like all who met her, I found Dame Dorothy to be a very warm and compassionate person who was truly dedicated to the people's side of politics. This is amply borne out by even the most cursory reading of her career. From the age of 16 Dame Dorothy was a staunch Labor Party supporter, but her appeal transcended party political boundaries. This was very evident to me when I attended her funeral on 6 June. A large gathering of mourners from all walks of life and from all sides of the political spectrum was testimony to the great admiration and respect which she commanded.

I am very proud to have met Dame Dorothy Margaret Tangney, to have made her acquaintance, and to represent the Federal seat which bears her name. With her passing Australia has lost one of her social pioneering daughters. On behalf of the people of Tangney, I convey our deepest sympathy to her family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dame Dorothy Tangney, the first woman to serve in the Australian Senate and part of a family of nine children, a family facing hardship, carried out all her duties with an outstanding capability and with an understanding of the needs of the working people, true to the Labor movement of which she was part and of which she was very proud. At a time when the contribution which women could make to public life was not popularly recognised, let alone appreciated, she paved the way for other women, including those in this House. She is remembered by Australian women with warmth and with gratitude, and I pay tribute to her.

—I join other members in paying tribute to Dame Dorothy Tangney. As a Western Australian member of this House I feel privileged to have followed the first Western Australian woman to sit in the national Parliament. Often in years past I have called upon the political experiences of Dame Dorothy for direct-ion and inspiration. Very few women have served in this Parliament and I can imagine how daunting it must have been to be the first. We have heard today how exceptionally well she carried out her role as a senator. Dame Dorothy was a role model for all women wanting to enter parliament. I pay tribute to this great woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the motion of condolence moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). As he pointed out, Dame Dorothy Tangney was a woman from a humble background who never lost sight of her origins. She was motivated to enter Parliament because she felt that it was unfair that some people appeared to have everything while others were in desperate need, and she used her energy and talent as a senator to do positive things to correct this imbalance. She was an architect, along with other members of the Australian Labor Party social services committee, of many of today's social benefits. The fact that we have unemployment and sickness benefits, and the fact that pensions are paid to deserted wives and wives of prisoners, is largely due to the efforts of Dame Dorothy Tangney. All of these benefitswere designed to assist people who are disadvantaged, usually though no fault of their own.

SPEECH.PARA: It was fitting that a seat of the Federal Parliament should be named after her, and, like the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) and the current member for Tangney (Mr Shack), I was proud to have been first elected to Parliament in the seat that bore her name. She was a great lady of the Australian Parliament and of the Australian Labor Party. I join with my colleagues from both Houses in extending condolences to the family of Dame Dorothy Tangney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I should like to add my remarks to those condolences expressed in memory of Dame Dorothy Tangney. The Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) said many of the things of a personal nature that I would have said, so I shall not go over that ground. My memories of Dame Dorothy are largely personal. Her career in Parliament roughly coincided with that of my father. I can recollect meeting her on many occasions in a family situation. She had a very great sense of family, an Irish sense of family. That was very important in her preserving her sense of humour in the conditions in which she found herself living, in places such as the Kurrajong Hotel, with colleagues, as described by the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair). She required a sense of humour to cope with that situation, and she required also a substantial sense of humour to be a Labor member of parliament for a substantial part of the period from 1949 to 1972. It is a great thing that, since she left Parliament, she was celebrated in the way in which she has been by the hanging of her portrait in this building, by her recognition with an honour, and by the substantial tributes that have been paid to her here today.

SPEECH.PARA: Dame Dorothy was one of a very substantial number of Labor members during that period who, in the normal course of political events, might have aspired to a ministerial position and an opportunity to do, in a much more systematic way, the things that are open to a member of the Executive but are not necessarily open to a member of the Parliament. All that one can say of Dame Dorothy in that regard is that insofar as members of parliament on an individual basis are capable of having a substantial impact on public policy, on the type of legislation by which this nation is governed, Dame Dorothy went about as far as any individual member of parliament could in making a substantial contribution to this country's future.

My other personal involvement with Dame Dorothy was partly political. One of the earlier jobs I had to do was to scrutinise preferences in the ballot in which Dame Dorothy was finally removed-reluctantly, as she has revealed-from this Parliament in 1967. I had the futile task of trying to shift votes off the Liberal candidates on to the Labor candidate over a two-day or three-day period, and whilst we were able to get rid of a few hundred Liberal votes here and there, they were not, in the event, sufficient. One of the notable features of that ballot, which is probably now forgotten, is that in an electoral process which is cruel to individual candidates, Dame Dorothy polled a very substantial personal vote, although it was not, unfortunately, sufficient for her to be able to secure an extension of a very distinguished parliamentary career.

As I have said, Dame Dorothy had a great sense of family. That sense of family was obvious in the way in which she treated her many relatives, many of whom looked to her to a considerable degree for their support through life, and a very large number of people in Western Australia will have felt a very substantial loss since Dame Dorothy died.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPOINTMENT OF CLERK OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Governor-General in Council has agreed to my recommendation and appointed Mr Alan Browning, a Deputy Clerk of the House, to be Clerk of the House of Representatives on and from 31 July 1985.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 May, I presented a special report of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings relating to the broadcasting of excerpts of proceedings on Australian radio and television stations. Shortly after the presentation of the report the House agreed to the authorisation of the broadcasting of excerpts under such conditions as were determined by the Committee.

INTERJECT.PARA: Appended to the special report were guidelines governing access by media organisations to the audio signal of proceedings for the purposes of taking excerpts. The Joint Committee subsequently met and considered those guidelines in the light of media comment on their desirability and practicability. As a result the Committee has determined conditions of access which I now present for the information of honourable members. The conditions as determined represent some modification to the original guidelines. One of the areas of greatest significance to which I draw the attention of honourable members is that the Committee has determined that for the length of the trial period excerpts may be taken from adjournment debates and proceedings after 11.30 p.m., which are not currently broadcast live.

Other modifications are that the guidelines now spell out that excerpts are not to be used for the purposes of political party advertising or in election campaigns, and they now state explicitly that qualified privilege only shall apply to broadcasters. Another modification is that the fortnightly return which was previously required to be provided to the Committee by media organisations is no longer a requirement for access to the signal. Alternative monitoring arrangements have been entered into, and I will present to the House a return drawn from the monitoring at the conclusion of the trial period.

I remind honourable members that from the commencement of proceedings today excerpts of debates and proceedings may be taken by broadcasting organisations for later broadcasting. Honourable members will also be aware that the House has authorised the televising of portions of the proceedings relating to the Budget speeches of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). Guidelines concerning the television coverage have been agreed to and I present a copy of them for the information of honourable members.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS: REQUESTS FOR DETAILED INFORMATION

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 February 1980, Mr Speaker Snedden made a statement to the House concerning new arrangements by which members could seek detailed information on the parliamentary departments for which the Presiding Officers are responsible. Since then the practice has been that, where a member desired to ask a question relating to the administration of any of the departments of the Parliament, the member indicated to the Clerk that he or she intended to lodge with the Speaker a request for information. At the conclusion of the next Question Time, the Speaker called the member to indicate his or her intention to make the request and, after the member had done so, the Speaker asked that the request, in writing, be handed to the Clerk.

INTERJECT.PARA: I have reviewed this practice and decided that the need for the member to indicate in the House an intention to lodge a request is an unnecessary procedure. In future a member need only lodge his or her request with the Clerk either directly or through the medium of the Table Office. This will make the arrangements similar to those which apply to Questions on Notice. No other change is proposed. If the request is in order, it will be published in the next issue of Hansard and I will provide, in due course, a written reply which will also be printed in Hansard. The existing procedure-whereby less detailed requests for information may be asked orally of the Speaker-continues without change.

TALK.START.PARA: —From time to time I note the presence in the galleries of former long-serving members of the Parliament. I note today the presence of Frank O'Keefe, the former long-serving member for Paterson. I am surprised that he has come back to see us so soon, but I am sure honourable members will give him a warm welcome.

—What action is the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations taking to ensure that the lawful agreement made between the Mudginberri abattoir and its employees under a legitimate Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission award is protected from union action which is both illegal and in contradiction of clear Commission rulings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has been very concerned about this dispute which, although covering only a small number of employees, is obviously a matter of much greater national import. Many issues are involved and I will not canvass them in this response. Later in the day there will be an opportunity to go into them in more depth. Let me say, briefly, that the Government has been concerned to do all that it can to end the industrial action which has taken place in response to the Commission's decision. It is highly regrettable that the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union has seen fit to take direct action against the Commission's decision. One can understand in some respects its concern about the wider implications of the decision that was made. Nevertheless, that is something that should be dealt with in the industrial processes and not by direct action.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to inform the House that the Government has been attempting to ensure that this matter is dealt with properly through the industrial processes and that today the AMIEU has decided to seek to take this matter back to the Commission.

The precise form of its application is not yet known to me. This matter will be resolved only by the processes before the Commission. It is a nonsense to argue that it can be resolved by resorting to action in the industrial court. The whole array of action taking place there is making it more difficult to resolve this issue.

In relation to the picket which applies at the Mudginberri abattoir, I am not able to say when it will be lifted but I would expect that to be done very shortly because there would be no way in which the Commission would hear any application from the AMIEU before the picket was lifted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of the Minister for Trade's impending visit to China I ask him to provide the House with the latest available figures on Australia's exports to China. Do those figures provide further evidence of the robust state of the Australian economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Stirling for his question. It is true that next week I will be spending a few days in China continuing the good work that was done by my predecessor and, more latterly, by the Prime Minister and a number of other Ministers who have been working very diligently to secure a long term and mutually beneficial trading relationship with the People's Republic of China. The results of those efforts are beginning to show up in the statistics in a very tangible form. The figures for 1984-85, which have just become available, indicate that Australia's exports to China jumped by some 73.4 per cent in that year and passed the $1 billion mark for the first time.

ANSWER.PARA: The principal item remains wheat, but at just under 29 per cent it represents a smaller share than it usually does as our exports across the board increase and the relationship becomes much broader and one which is likely to endure and continue to grow.

It is my intention on Thursday to make a more detailed statement about the developing relationship with China, but we are seeing an increasing number of visits by important Chinese political figures and, indeed, from commercial and other provincial delegations coming from China to Australia. There was one just yesterday from Jiangsu province. I think what is interesting about this whole development is that there is a very real concern on the part of the Chinese, as there is on the part of the Australian Government, to see this relationship develop into the future. There was a very successful mission involving transport matters just recently which Senator Button and I were able to follow up in Sydney last week. There was a very enthusiastic reception on the part of representatives of the private and public transport sectors in Australia to the report of that delegation. I think that that delegation through the setting up of a very high level co-ordinating group between Australia and China will see new opportunities develop in the transport sector as well. If we are able to nurture this relationship we will see it grow in a way which is of benefit not only to Australia but also to the the People's Republic of China.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations another question on Mudginberri. How does the Minister justify the failure of Commonwealth meat inspectors to cross the illegal Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union picket line at Mudginberri? Why does the Government, by its inaction, support this illegal picket which continues in clear defiance of lawfully made orders of the Federal Court of Australia?

—In answer to the first part of the question, it is not for me to justify the actions of the Australian Public Service Meat Inspectors Association. If the honourable member wants to know the answer to that question he should ask the meat inspectors, not me. In regard to the second part of the question, the Government has taken some action in regard to the meat inspectors. This is a matter again which we will go into in greater detail later on, but it is a fact that the meat inspectors were asked to cross the picket line and that when they refused to do so they were stood down. It is also the case that the three meat inspectors involved were off the site for some three weeks, from about the end of May to about 24 June. Whether they are regarded as being stood down or on strike is perhaps a matter of semantics. The fact is that they refused to cross the picket line and, therefore, were not paid for that time. It is a nonsense to say that the Government has taken no action. Furthermore, the Government's actions have been the subject of appeal to the Federal Court in respect of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act and the Government's actions were thoroughly upheld by the Federal Court. So the government has nothing to apologise for in relation to that matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Science explain what role the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation will play in the development of Australia's space industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Dunkley for his question. I will take it slowly for the benefit of the honourable member for Tangney.
—Order! As long as the honourable member makes it brief.

—CSIRO has designated space research and development as a high priority area. It has set up the CSIRO Office of Space Science and Applications-COSSA-to develop and implement space policy and planning. It is collaborating with Landsat to develop an experimental system to receive and process the greatly improved data available from the new generation of Landsat satellites. This of course will be of enormous significance to the mining industry, the resource industry and agriculture generally.

ANSWER.PARA: The world will be entering a new era of space use with space stations in the mid-1990s. CSIRO is participating in several international studies to define research goals. We are also developing a number of specific technologies that have very broad application, not only in the communications industry but also, of course, in micro-electronics generally and in satellites, on which we are increasingly dependent, both for entertainment and for meteorology, commercial information and a whole variety of other areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct another question to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Again, in the light of the Mudginberri abattoir dispute, will the Minister now concede that sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act are the only pieces of effective legislation which protect employers and employees from illegal trade union action? Will the Minister now categorically state that he and the Government have abandoned any further attempts to remove this legislation from the statute books?
—The answer to both parts of the question is no, I will not.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REVIEW CONFERENCE OF THE TREATY ON THE NON-PROLIFERATION OF NUCLEAR WEAPONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What importance does the Government place on the Review Conference of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, particularly in relation to arms control?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be leaving on Saturday to go to Geneva to participate in the Review Conference on the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. Australia will be putting forward certain points at that conference about the need to persevere with the non-proliferation treaty regime and to try to encourage non-signatory nations to become signatories of the treaty. That in itself, as the Leader of the Opposition knows from past experience, is a daunting task. More specifically, we will be seeking to encourage supplier countries of nuclear technologies and resources for peaceful purposes to ensure that the full scope safeguards monitored by the International Atomic Energy Agency are applied where those transactions take place. In doing that, we will be very much putting to the fore the propositions which were explicit in the Slatyer report on the nuclear industry as it would affect this country. Beyond that, we are proceeding with our efforts to have put in place a comprehensive test ban treaty which goes beyond the non-proliferation treaty review. Of course, that matter is also under consideration at Geneva.

ANSWER.PARA: Those points, and the recent achievement of the Prime Minister at the Pacific Forum Conference, where he was successful in having concluded a treaty for a nuclear-free zone for the South Pacific-a signal achievement and one of only three such treaties in the world, the others being the Treaty of Tlatelolco, covering the Latin American countries, and a very special one covering Antarctica-I think represent quite convincingly the credentials and determination of this Government in its pursuit of arms control and disarmament. We will continue to pursue these matters.

We are fortunate in having an Ambassador for Disarmament who is active, in Geneva and elsewhere in multilateral fora, in promoting Australia's concern on these matters. With recent developments which are in prospect in the area of the nuclear arms race, it is absolutely essential that countries such as Australia maximise every opportunity presented to them to try to mobilise international support designed to bring about pressure, which, hopefully, will result in a curbing of the arms race, followed by a reduction in nuclear arms. One day we may even be fortunate enough to see the elimination of nuclear arms and effective control on conventional arms. I regret that those developments are beyond my lifetime.

TALK.START.PARA: — My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industry. In view of the fact that the Government has refused since May to take the necessary actions to provide Commonwealth meat inspectors at the Mudginberri abattoir, will the Minister immediately authorise Northern Territory inspectors, who continue to work at Mudginberri, to certify produce for export so that the abattoir can commence fulfilling its export meat contracts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question is very interesting. The Opposition really does not seem to have an idea of its own. On one day we hear an argument from the National Farmers Federation and a day or two later the Opposition issues a Press release picking up the same point. What is now happening in this dispute is that the Opposition and people such as the Queensland Premier are seizing on it for political purpose and are trying to exacerbate the dispute. What the Government is about is dispute settlement; it is not about dispute widening. All we hear from the Opposition is a lot of political parroting from members who are prepared to use this dispute for their own murky political purposes. If honourable members opposite really want to understand why the Government has been taking the position it has taken, they should first of all read the affidavit that went before the Federal Court-that is a public document-and also the decision of Mr Justice Neaves on this whole matter. They would do that if they were seriously interested in the facts relating to this dispute and the reasons why the Government has taken the actions it has taken.

ANSWER.PARA: To do as the honourable member for Gwydir suggests would not be in the interests of the meat industry and is not consistent with the Government's policy in its attempts to resolve this dispute. The Government has consistently taken action to ensure that this dispute between the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union and the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia at Mudginberri does not become a major dispute involving the whole meat industry on an ongoing basis, with substantial adverse national implications for that industry and for Australia's reputation as a reliable exporter of agricultural products. The Court has backed the decision-making process of the Government in dismissing the case brought against the Government by Mudginberri. It needs to be said again and again that this dispute is between the AMIEU and MATFA. The Government is not an employer involved in the principal dispute. The Court has determined that the action being taken by the AMIEU at Mudginberri is illegal. The Government is not condoning any of that illegal action. This is being handled by the courts; the court process is still under way.

The Government is not taking sides. It has taken several steps to try to resolve the dispute, including four times directing Commonwealth meat inspectors assigned to Mudginberri to report for duty and facilitating negotiations between the principal parties. Unfortunately, one side, the AMIEU, is persisting with action which is illegal and which the Court has determined is illegal. The other side, MATFA, with the urging and support of the NFF and people such as Bjelke-Petersen, wishes to engage us in actions which would escalate the dispute, for its own organisational purposes. The Commonwealth has been trying to contain the dispute and to get Mudginberri producing again, but MATFA and the NFF, which has bought into this dispute, will not even attend a round table conference organised by the Government to deal with the issues at the basis of this dispute. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has told the House that some of the Government's efforts in this matter are now being successful, and we may see some resolution of the dispute. We will not get dispute resolution in a matter as complex as this, concerning the issue of union coverage and section 45D, if people use this dispute for their own murky political purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs aware of allegations that the new immigration guidelines are biased against people from certain national, ethnic or cultural backgrounds? Are these allegations correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the alleg-ations and they are not correct. They relate to just one part of the immigration program; that which is for extended families-the brothers, sisters and non-dependent children. They relate to the fact that, in spite of the Government's having changed the planning levels, to increase from 14,000 to 16,000 the numbers coming in under the extended families program, it was necessary at the same time to tighten the points system. The reason for that was that two-thirds of the way through the last financial year, 1984-85, we had already filled the planning level. To continue to have a rationing system which at the end of the financial year would not bring us out somewhere near the numbers in the program for the planning level for that particular category just could not be condoned.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government looked at the best way of revising that points system. I am glad to say that there is bipartisan support for the approach we took; namely, that employability should be the key when we need that points system to ration the numbers. I am glad to tell the honourable member for Calwell and the House that `employability' does not necessarily mean the ability to speak English. One does not need to be able to speak English, for instance, to be a chef in a Greek restaurant and one will not be required to do so under our points system. But we have to face the fact that in many cases English is required, particularly in our service industries, where a lot of jobs are available. However, we will make sure that that requirement does not discriminate against any particular race. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has advised me that the Government has agreed to consult widely on the provisions of the legislation and that as of now something like 95 per cent of the recommendations of the advisory committee on the repatriation legislation, chaired by the National Chairman of the Returned Services League, Sir William Keys, have been included in the Veterans' Entitlements Bill. ANSWER.PARA: On the second aspect of the honourable members question, the allegation that the Government has reversed the onus of proof and imposed an onus on the claimant to prove his or her case is wrong. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that all members of this House realise the very serious situation in the sugar industry. We have to understand and accept that we are in a very different ball game with respect to this industry. This is not just a cyclical downturn. Quite a few things have happened and we are having to look at this industry in a far different light. Of course, the Federal Government is willing to provide meaningful assistance to the sugar industry which, as I have said, is suffering mainly from the ravages of the selfish and destructive policies of the European Economic Community in subsidising sales of sugar to the extent of $350 a tonne, and the policies of countries such as the United States of America, which is also supporting its industry. They are the two main causes, but as well as those there is a world oversupply of sugar as a lot of countries were encouraged into its production.

ANSWER.PARA: The assistance to the Australian industry should be integrated and should take at least three forms. First of all there should be adjustment assistance to help those people with basic long term viability in the industry, in the form of carry-on finance, debt reconstruction and those sorts of measures. Secondly, there should be the removal of the Queensland State Government's regulations which are adding to the costs of the industry and preventing adjustment that would help the industry with its cost structure. Thirdly, there is a need for the provision of price support by both the State and the Federal governments to keep what is the world's most technically efficient sugar industry operating until some sort of international agreement can restore some semblance of normality or sense to this world sugar market.

It has to be integrated and it has to take into account the three things I have enumerated. I emphasise that we want to help as soon as possible. There is an absolute need for both governments to work together and to make a financial contribution to this industry. So far no date that I have suggested has been suitable to Mr Turner. I trust this is not the reticence of Mr Turner or the Queensland Government to discuss the matter, nor intimidation by the Premier of that State.

DEBATE.TITLE: INQUIRY INTO THE COMMUNITY HOUSING EXPANSION PROGRAM IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On 19 July this year, I requested Mr Brian O'Dovovan, a former Commonwealth Crown Solicitor, to inquire into and report upon the operation of the community housing expansion program in the Australian Capital Territory. The Government appreciates the thorough and expeditious manner in which his report was completed and presented to it. This investigation was instituted following doubts about whether there was adequate protection of the Commonwealth's interests in the allocation of some $1.4m under the community housing expansion program in the Australian Capital Territory, and in particular the circumstances surrounding a grant of $133,000 to the Wyuna community.

SPEECH.PARA: As I announced on 19 July 1985, the Government commissioned Mr O'Donovan to inquire into and report on:
(a) All aspects of the financial and administrative arrangements concerned with grants under the Australian Capital Territory CHEP and, in particular, the grant to Wyuna Community Incorporated;

(b) The adequacy and effectiveness of existing safeguards of the Commonwealth's interests in properties purchased with grants under the Australian Capital Territory CHEP and funds provided for purchase of such properties; and
(c) Measures which might reasonably be taken to ensure that the Commonwealth's interests are fully protected.
Mr O'Dovovan reported to the Government last week, and at the conclusion of this statement I will be tabling his report.

I should say at the outset that Mr O'Donovan's report states that expenditure on the program has increased the stock of housing in the Australian Capital Territory available to low income earners. This accords with the aims of the program. However, Mr O'Donovan believes the existing safeguards of the Commonwealth's interests are inadequte, and he has recommended a number of additional measures. In considering these recommendations the Government decided that, in regard to the Australian Capital Territory community housing expansion program, it is of paramount importance that action be taken to ensure the maximum protection of the Commonwealth's interests, with the objectives of the program being a secondary issue. Accordingly, the Government has decided that officers from my Department and the Attorney-General's Department will negotiate with existing recipients of CHEP grants for the maximum protection of the Commonwealth's interests. Wherever possible, the measures recommended by Mr O'Donovan will be implemented. These measures are, in essence, to obtain and register mortgages over properties already purchased and, where the purchase has not been completed, for a Commonwealth co-signatory to the bank account in which the CHEP grant is held. I will be receiving quarterly reports from the Secretary of my Department on each recipient's compliance with its deed of grant.

I should also point out that independently of the O'Donovan report, my Department and I had taken steps to secure the Commonwealth's interests. Formal breach procedures under Wyuna's deed of grant had been commenced and legal action initiated through the Australian Government Solicitor's Office. The other co-operatives had been contacted and asked to register the Commonwealth's interest on the title. Those with unspent grant money had been asked to agree to the Commonwealth being a co-signatory on the relevant bank account. An examination of all other non-statutory grant schemes in my Department had been commenced. Early this year I decided that I would not be seeking funds for CHEP in the 1985-86 financial year and on 18 July I announced a consultancy to examine the need for and form of alternative public housing in the Australian Capital Territory.

There is a need for further action and for improvement of the administration of my Department. Accordingly, the Secretary will be developing proposals to improve the management of the Housing Branch and will also review other schemes in my Department with the aim of improving the relationship between the management tasks of the Department and the resources available to it. It is likely that one or two officers from elsewhere in the Public Service will be temporarily seconded to assist departmental management in this task.

The report identifies the problems which can arise when a body which is independent and outside ministerial control is given responsibility for determining the objectives, criteria and recipients of grants. These issues raise significant problems of general application, including:
the need for a clear distinction between the responsibilities of Ministers and Departments and the responsibilities of the outside body;
the need for a clear separation between the making of recommendations on individual proposals and the encouragement, facilitation and development of those proposals;
the establishment of clear criteria or guidelines for assessment of proposals before funds are made available; and
identification of all resource requirements, including those needed for effective administration, when considering proposals for new initiatives.

Accordingly, the Government has decided that the Departments of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and Finance and the Public Service Board are to prepare a report on the Service-wide implications and on ways and means of ensuring more effective systems for administration and financial supervision of non-statutory grant programs.

As I mentioned, the Commonwealth has already taken action in the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court in relation to the grant made to Wyuna Community Incorporated. The Government has given careful consideration to whether it should table the whole of the O'Donovan report given that litigation has commenced. It believes, however, that discussion on matters of this kind should not be stifled merely because there is civil litigation pending, because of the greater public interest in upholding freedom of discussion on matters of general public concern. However, while the raising of these matters in Parliament is protected by Parliamentary privilege and is consistent with the sub judice convention, care needs to be taken with the reporting of these matters outside Parliament. That is a matter on which elements of the media should take their own counsel.

The actions taken, and to be taken, by the Government in regard to the Australian Capital Territory CHEP recognise financial and administrative deficiencies. I conclude by quoting the final paragraph of the O'Donovan report:

. . . I would express my agreement with the view that the identity of persons associated with an application for a CHEP grant cannot, as such, be a relevant consideration in deciding whether or not the application should succeed. I would also wish to record that I have no reason to believe that any person concerned in making the recommendation for the grant to Wyuna acted other than honestly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon P.A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am forced to comment on the statement made by the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) because it is nothing more than a farrago of nonsense teased together with an icing of hocus-pocus. The simple fact of the matter is that we are talking about a community housing expansion program. One would think that that is a very simple matter. One would think that the formulation of such a program would be well within the capability of almost any department of state. It is the sort of program for which there are numerous precedents. SPEECH.PARA: This so-called community housing expansion program was set up by the former Minister for Territories and Local Government, the present Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren), in August 1983. I understand that he said that he was confident that the CHEP would `set a national precedent for increased flexibility in public housing'. It is flexible all right! TALK.START.PARA: —He did. He just did not give it to you. He sent it to your officials.
—He did not send me a copy. Paragraph (d) on page 40 of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The guidelines adopted for 1983-84 were so highly flexible that they could not, I think, be regarded as a program.
That is what Mr O'Donovan said. The last sentence of the guidelines reads:
Proposal (sic) will not be automatically disqualified on the grounds of not meeting any or all of the above criteria.

It is unbelievable. One would have thought that that was elementary and that it was hardly necessary for someone to have to inquire into and report on a housing scheme of this nature. TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter of privilege following the indulgence that was given to me and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) a little while ago relating to a matter of requests in a question without notice and the answer to it. I believe that the indulgence given to us both gave the Minister an opportunity to reply because I had advised him previously that I was going to raise this matter of indulgence and I had stated the basis on which I was going to raise it. It became obvious from the answers given that the Minister did not regard the omission as a mistake or an oversight but as premeditated. I suggest that the Minister could use this as a precedent for future occasions when a member of the Opposition asks a question on notice and the answer is not given to him. This could be used as a precedent.

SPEECH.PARA: Could I give the background to the question of privilege as I see it. I listed a question on notice in connection with the categorisation of hospitals, which was the subject of a report, and some of the hospitals within my area were to be affected. This information was not something that I ran with myself-it was given to me. The question contained an element which required having to wait until the end of June for information for that year. The answer to the question was received by the Clerk of the House on 30 July 1985. Standing order 150 states:

The reply to a question on notice shall be given by delivering the same to the Clerk. A copy thereof shall be supplied to the Member who has asked the question, and such question and reply shall be printed in Hansard.

I repeat: There has not been an opportunity for the question to appear in Hansard, and I received notice of the answer subsequent to 30 July 1985. As I suggested previously, it is a breach of privilege, a disobedience of the rules and orders of the House. The fact is that the answer, until it was given to the Clerk, was the property of no one but this Parliament The House of Representatives Practice on page 501 refers to answers to questions on notice. While it does not deal specifically with this situation of another session of Parliament, it does state:
An answer to a question on notice must be relevant to the question.
An answer is given by delivering it to the Clerk who must supply a copy to the Member who asked the question and arrange for both question and reply to be printed in Hansard.
That was done.
In addition the Clerk arranges for copies to be supplied to the Press.

I am suggesting that the Clerk, after 30 July, has the right to supply copies to the Press, but he certainly has not got that right beforehand because he does not know the facts of the answer. I am suggesting that 30 July is the operative time. The House of Representatives Practice continues:

Answers are neither read nor tabled in the House. Answers delivered to the Clerk after the prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House cannot be accepted. In these circumstances the Minister concerned may supply the answer directly to the questioner and, if he wishes, to the Press.

I suggest that that indicates that at no time was the answer to that question the property of anybody but this Parliament. It was not up to the Minister to give notice of the answer to the question to somebody else, as he did at least a week before. I am relying on a report from the Mackay Daily Mercury on 24 July, which refers to the question I asked and the answer that was given. The facts contained in that publication, a week before the answer was received by the Clerk, are identical to the answers to the question. I suggest that the Minister's response indicates that he intends this to be a precedent, and that is really an obstruction of the manner in which an appointed representative of this House goes about his duty. He has not been given the full courtesies and I believe it is a breach of privilege.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Federal Government will allocate sufficient funds to the Australia Council specifically to ensure ongoing funding to State Arts Councils to enable those organisations to maintain access to performing and other arts activities in country and outer metropolitan areas.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the current policies of the Community Arts Board of the Australia Council are disadvantaging regional residents (country and outer metropolitan) with regard to the provision of access to art forms, in particular to tours of professional performing arts.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Federal Government will allocate sufficient funds to the Australia Council specifically to ensure ongoing funding to State Arts Councils to enable those organisations to maintain access to performing and other arts activities in country and outer metropolitan areas.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfuly showeth:

Our alarm and concern at the proposed cutback of funding for pre-school and child-care. The withdrawal of funding will adversely affect the operation of childhood centres, thereby affecting young families, women`s employment prospects and children`s development in their most formative years.
We deplore the attitude, by the government, that young children and family life is regarded as having little significance within this society.
We urge you to reverse proposals for cuts in children's services and maintain present funding.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of State Arts Council
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the current policies of the Community Arts Board of the Australia Council are disadvantaging rural residents with regard to access to the Arts.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Federal Government will allocate sufficient funds to the Australia Council specifically to ensure ongoing funding to State Arts Councils to enable those organisations to maintain access to performing and other arts activities in country areas.
