DEBATE.TITLE: DAIRY INDUSTRY STABILIZATION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the Senate acquainting the House that the Senate presses its request for an amendment to the Bill.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of the House to the constitutional question that this message involves. The message purports to repeat the request for an amendment contained in Message No. 69, which the House rejected at its sitting of 23 May. The `right' of the Senate to repeat and thereby press or insist on a request for an amendment has never been accepted by the House of Representatives. On several previous occasions when a request was pressed on the House by repetition the House had regard to the claim that the public welfare required passage of the legislation which was the subject of the pressed request and gave the pressed request the House's consideration notwithstanding that the House resolved to refrain from determining its constitutional rights. The House so informed the Senate of the terms of its resolution in its message to the Senate in reply.

INTERJECT.PARA: It is not certain whether the Senate's `right' to press a request by repetition is justiciable in the courts. However it is a matter of constitutional propriety as between the Houses based on the provisions of sections 53 to 57 of the Constitution. Strong arguments that the Constitution does not give the Senate the right to press a request were advanced by Quick and Garran, who were intimately involved in the development of the Constitution. Their views may be found on pages 671-2 of their classic analysis of the Constitution. In 1943, some 40 years later, the question was examined by four eminent constitutional lawyers, Garran, Knowles, Bailey and Castieau, who, after considering other learned opinion, summed up the question in the following words:

In our opinion, the Constitution in denying the right of amendment and conferring the right of request intended a substantial difference. In this we respectfully agree with the views expressed by Sir Harrison Moore, Sir Isaac Isaacs, and Sir John Latham. We think it clear that the Constitution did not intend to stultify itself by giving back in one clause what it had taken away in another. The essence of the difference between request and amendment is that in the case of a request the right of decision as to the form of the Bill rests solely with the House of Representatives. To press a request is to insist upon it-which is a contradiction in terms, and also in our opinion unconstitutional . . . .

Other more recent legal opinion has been of a similar view, including the opinions of Professor J. E. Richardson, Professor Geoffrey Sawer and Professor Dennis Pearce. I respectfully have to agree with those opinions and I point out that this statement is consistent with the view taken by my predecessor, Speaker Snedden, on the last occasion when this question arose, which was on 21 October 1981. It rests with the House whether it will consider message No. 108 insofar as it purports to press the request that was contained in message No. 69.

(1) That this House endorses the statement of Mr Speaker in relation to the constitutional questions raised by message No. 108 transmitted from the Senate in relation to the Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Amendment Bill 1985;
(2) That this House declines to consider message No. 108 insofar as it purports to press the request that was contained in message No. 69 from the Senate; and
(3) That the consideration of further action in relation to the Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Amendment Bill 1985 be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's complicity in support of the illegal AMIEU picket line at Mudginberri abattoir.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance refers to an historic struggle which is being fought out in the Northern Territory, far from our southern cities and suburbs and miles from the workshops and factories of urban Australia. It is a struggle which may well become a turning point in the history of industrial relations in Australia and the history of our future economic development. Indeed, a victory for justice over intimidation in the Mudginberri abattoir dispute could well constitute a turning point in the history of the Australian nation. Mudginberri abattoir may be a small, far-flung outpost in the middle of northern Australia, but what is taking place there is no insignificant matter. If a just outcome is won in the Mudginberri abattoir dispute, there will be new hope for employees who wish to throw off the yoke of dictatorial unionism, there will be new hope for employers who wish to join their employees in a joint quest for greater mutual rewards and there will be new hope for Australia to embark on a new epoch of growth and prosperity. A just outcome must be won.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone who is familiar with the facts of the dispute could not fail to side with Jay Pendarvis, the owner of the Mudginberri abattoir, and his employees, the men who are fighting the oppressive stance of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union every bit as hard as their employer. Today the Opposition condemns the Hawke Government's collusion with the AMIEU in the Mudginberri dispute. We condemn the tacit support this Government is giving to a union which is down and, if it was not for the Government's support, would be out as well. We condemn the Government's complicity in the union's persecution of the Mudginberri abattoir and its employees.

The AMIEU is wrong. This is not just the coalition's opinion; it is the opinion of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the Federal Court of Australia as well; yet the Hawke Government is colluding with this union. The Government is supporting a union in defiance of the very judicial and industrial relations institutions which the Government is responsible for administering. The Government through its inaction is undermining the decisions of those institutions, instead of upholding their authority by urging compliance with them. Regrettably, this is what we have come to expect from this Government; a Government so keen to back the unions in their increasing and unceasing campaign to deny the rule of law, defy our industrial relations institutions and trample on individual's rights.

Before detailing the Government's shabby and shameful support for this union, I wish to outline briefly the facts of the dispute, facts which have been subsumed generally in media reporting of the court dramas that have accompanied the dispute. Fact 1: The Arbitration Commission created an award covering the meat industry in the Northern Territory, the Northern Territory Meat Processing Award 1984. It is an Arbitration Commission award like any other. For the benefit of those who wish to avail themselves of it, it provides employers and employees with the option of making their own agreements resulting in above award wages in exchange for higher productivity. Under the terms of the award, no meat worker could earn less than the wage otherwise prescribed in it. No meat worker could earn less. Note and note well: The agreement between Jay Pendarvis and his employees was made under an Arbitration Commission award and is supported by subsequent Commission rulings.

Mudginberri abattoir was set to operate like a rocket, ready to fulfil its export meat contracts at record speed, with meat workers there being paid double the wage otherwise prescribed in the award. Exploitation-one has to be kidding! I have been up there, in company with the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), and we have seen for ourselves. All of those Australians who watched 60 Minutes on Sunday can be assured that that program was accurate. Mudginberri abattoir is the very model of how employers and employees both can win by getting together and making their own voluntary agreements.

What of the union, the AMIEU? It is in the superbly ironic position of trying to force down the wages of the Mudginberri meat workers. The union is trying to force down the workers' wages. These so-called heroes of the working class, the officials of the AMIEU, are trying to bully the Mudginberri meat workers into accepting wages 50 per cent below what Jay Pendarvis is willing to pay them. I went out to the picket line and I felt sorry for those men living there in the dust, because where were the heroes of the working class, the officials of this union? They were miles away.

The Australian Council of Trade Unions should be cringing in shame that one of its member unions is oppressing workers in this fashion. It is not as if the Mudginberri meat workers are not willing to be union members. They were members of the union until they were kicked out in a fit of pique by the union bosses because they had the temerity to reach an agreement with their own employer. In fact, one of the conditions laid down by Mudginberri for settlement of this dispute is that its meat workers be readmitted to the union if they so wish. This is not union bashing; this is not an employer who is anti-union. Jay Pendarvis is an employer fighting for his right and his employees' right to work together happily under the terms and conditions of an Arbitration Commission award. He is happy for the Mudginberri meat workers to be members of the AMIEU, but he will not stand around and let the union screw him and his employees simply because the union was miffed because it was superfluous in the making of that agreement between the employer and his own employees.

What of the Hawke Government's role in the AMIEU campaign? The Government has been too clever by half. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) can say that he has directed export meat inspectors to cross the picket line and fulfil their duties at Mudginberri. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) can say that he offered to convene a meeting of interested parties to the dispute. Let us dig a little deeper and look at what the Government has and has not done with respect to the parties behaving lawfully in the Mudginberri dispute. Why has not the Minister for Primary Industry-he will get an opportunity to tell us in this debate-vested local Northern Territory meat inspectors with export meat inspection powers for the duration of the dispute? Where is the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins)? Does he care at all about the consequences of the union's belligerence towards Australia's meat export industry? Does he care about the hard won beef export quota we have with the European Economic Community? What about the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis)? If he is such a dedicated supporter of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, why has he not taken steps to ensure that the AMIEU abides by the Commission's decisions?

As for the Prime Minister, he has played a particularly pernicious role. Has the Prime Minister attempted to get the union to abide by the rulings of the Federal Court and the Arbitration Commission? No, he has not. Has the Prime Minister at any stage sought to use his special relationship with the trade union movement to make the union see the error of its ways? No, he has not. In fact, the Prime Minister has made a two-fold contribution in this dispute. He has breached the confidentiality of his communications with Jay Pendarvis-that is his first contribution. Who publicly released the confidential telex between Mudginberri and the Prime Minister? No prizes for guessing that it was the union. One must ask oneself the second question. Who gave it to the union? The Prime Minister's second great contribution was his suggestion to Ian McLachlan of the National Farmers Federation that the dispute could be brought back before the Commission. I ask why? Why should it be brought back to the Commission when Jay Pendarvis and his employees simply want to assert their right to work in compliance with the terms and conditions of an existing Arbitration Commission award, with the support of subsequent Arbitration Commission rulings? In any case, I have profound doubts that the union will be able to bring the matter back before the Commission as the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations suggested today in Question Time. Justice Morling of the Federal Court found on 12 July that in a legal sense no dispute existed between the Mudginberri abattoir and the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union. Of course, if no dispute legally exists it is not possible for the matter to be brought back within the Arbitration Commission's jurisdiction. This fact may have escaped the notice of the Minister-either that or he has been engaging in some wishful thinking.

Why do the Prime Minister and his Ministers for Primary Industry, Trade, and Employment and Industrial Relations continue to support through their inaction the efforts of a belligerent union to overturn the law and the Arbitration Commission's rulings? Why will they not support and make an effort to protect those who have right on their side in this dispute-Jay Pendarvis and his employees-against the party so clearly in the wrong, the AMIEU?

I regret to say that the Government has also made an additional contribution to the prolongation of this dispute. This is a factor which, above all others, has made the dispute chronic because it has led the union and the ACTU to believe that defiance of the law is acceptable and will be rewarded. I refer to the Government's continued willingness, confirmed again in Question Time today, to contemplate the repeal of the remaining sanctuary-the only remaining sanctuary-for those who seek to bring about compliance with Arbitration Commission rulings. I refer to sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act. The Minister was given a clear opportunity today to say categorically and once and for all that he would turn his back on attempts to remove these sections of the Trade Practices Act from the statute book. He said that he would not give that assurance. Every farmer, every small business person, every business person generally and every employee who is concerned about productivity, effort and reward will hear of the Minister's answer and will understand that while he and his Government survive there will be no protection in the industrial relations environment for any party that wishes to comply with the law, seek compliance with the law and be accountable under the law. The ACTU and its member unions are determined to get their way with sections 45D and E. They have not given up their campaign to break this part of the Act and the Government's passivity in the face of such flagrant breaches of an Act on its own statute book can be interpreted in only one way. The Minister has confirmed that again today. The Government has not given up its quest to remove that remaining protection from the statute book. If the Government succeeds in misrepresenting the Mudginberri dispute sufficiently well it will attempt to use it erroneously in support of another campaign to get rid of those parts of the Trade Practices Act. If that is not what the Government has on its mind, if that is not its ulterior motive in failing to protect the lawful against the lawless in this dispute, I do not know what is. The coalition will fight any such proposal tooth and nail.

In my closing remarks I wish to reflect on the positive side of this Mudginberri dispute. There is a positive side and it deserves much wider attention. That is the side in which an employer and employee, because of their relationships one to another, are able to determine mutually beneficial and voluntary arrangements which will result in both parties to that industrial relationship winning, benefiting and profiting. There is a revival going on in industrial relations in Australia. It will become a revolution. It is something that the Government does not understand and it is something that the recalcitrant members of the trade union movement do not understand-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —The anguished howls of the slavering hordes opposite are what we have come to expect whenever the term `trade union' is used in this place. They are all gathered here today to go through the usual performance. Let me say at the outset that in some ways I am sorry that the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), did not finish his speech because it would have been interesting to hear about this great new revolution. Doubtless we will have to hear about it from someone else or in some other debate. We look forward to hearing about this great revolution which is going to sweep through the industrial relations arena, because in the seven and a quarter years that the Fraser Government was in office it achieved a notoriously poor record, not only in relation to its handling of the economy where it proved conclusively it consisted of economic cretins, but also in relation to industrial relations where equally that Government proved totally incapable of reducing the level of industrial disputation in this country. Opposition members stand up here with a holier-than-thou, high moral tone to tell us about who is right and who is wrong in industrial disputes and what terrible things trade unions are. Those sorts of stances do absolutely nothing to achieve better industrial relations.
—And what would your credentials be?

—Will you just shut up and listen for a little while? The Opposition achieved nothing in government in terms of better industrial relations. The people of this country want a lower level of industrial disputes and a more civilised procedure for resolving industrial conflicts. That, of course, is what has happened since this Government has been in office. The context in which this debate takes place today is one in which there is a record low level of industrial disputation in this country. That is extremely important and very embarrassing to honourable members opposite who do not like to hear that sort of thing being said. They do not like to hear these facts which are recognised by the Australian populace. Nevertheless, it is the case that that is the environment in which this dispute has taken place. Honourable members should not tell us about revolutions and talk to us as if we have not achieved anything. We have the lowest level of time lost through industrial disputes since 1968. The Opposition should not talk about its revolutions-it had its chances and proved comprehensively incapable of having a process for resolving industrial conflict in this country which did not lead to a higher level of industrial dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: I was also interested in the part of the shadow Minister's contribution in which he said that he strongly supports our industrial institutions. I am very pleased to hear that because I thought he was really rather angry with our industrial institutions, that he thought their decisions were wrong on many occasions and that the whole system needed to be virtually thrown out and started again. But now he is saying that we should support those institutions and I am very pleased to hear that. I fully support the idea of supporting our industrial institutions. I look forward to the honourable member's support for future decisions that come from those industrial institutions rather than hearing the whinging screams that we have heard about the wages policy that has operated so successfully in this country over the past couple of years.
In relation to the topic that is before us, the Government totally refutes the terms of this matter of public importance:
The Government's complicity in support of the illegal AMIEU picket line at Mudginberri abattoir.

That is, of course, absolute and arrant nonsense. There is no complicity and the whole discussion starts on that totally false base which is not unusual in those speeches which come from the honourable member for Tangney. The Government has in no way connived with the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, let alone in this dispute. In relation to the operation of pickets, I will leave that exposition to my colleague the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). Let me say very briefly that the meat inspectors were ordered to go through that picket and when they did not do so they were stood down. That led to a substantial amount of time being lost by them. This Government's actions were upheld in the Federal Court of Australia when the matter was taken before it, so we have nothing to apologise for in that respect.

Let me move on to other aspects. There has been in this dispute a regrettable series of actions. Firstly, it is highly regrettable that the AMIEU has sought to take direct action against a decision by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That is something we regret very much. We understand in some respects why it is concerned about it, and I will come to that in a moment, but I cannot condone in any way the taking of direct action against a Commission decision. Let me say also that I regard as highly regrettable the actions of Mr Pendarvis, the Meat and Allied Trades Federation and the National Farmers Federation in resorting to the use of section 45D in relation to this dispute-I will come to that also in a moment-because that action has proved totally futile. Despite an incredible array of actions before the Federal Court in relation to the use of section 45D, the picket line has not been taken away and therefore has not been successful in what it aimed to achieve and is not leading to a resolution of the dispute. I will come back to that point also.

I also regret very much the actions of the National Farmers Federation, which is really an extremely marginal player in this dispute, and yet I believe it has taken a leading role in goading Mr Pendarvis into taking a much harder line than might otherwise have have been the case, and therefore in making this dispute infinitely more difficult to settle. I understand that the National Farmers Federation has guaranteed half of Mr Pendarvis's legal costs and is also providing other support to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?

—The honourable member can form his own judgment about that, but I believe it shows the involvement of the National Farmers Federation in an issue which, on the face of it, does not directly concern it. Without doubt it has tried to pursue its own objectives and to use Mr Pendarvis and this dispute for its own purposes, and I will come back in a moment to what its purposes are.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also the case, and highly regrettable, that conservative political parties in this country have sought to use this dispute for their own political advantage. Yesterday the Premier of Queensland said that not only does he support Mr Pendarvis, which of course is his absolute right, but also he is going to ensure funding of Mr Pendarvis. I am not sure how he is going to do that, what funds he is providing, but it certainly indicated that he has direct interests in this which go beyond just those of an interested observer.

The Federal Opposition is also seeking to use this dispute to try to improve its political fortunes. Therefore this dispute, which is a very small one involving a couple of dozen employees and one employer, has taken on far greater national importance, at least in part because of the actions of various groups who are seeking to use it for their own purposes. This dispute is really about the tally system and the objections that the National Farmers Federation have to that system, and its desire to destroy it and the union's desire to retain it. That is what the dispute is basically about. The tally system has applied in the industry for many decades and operates in all States of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is backed by the Meat and Allied Trades Federation.

—It is supported also, as my colleague the Minister for Primary Industry reminds me, by the Meat and Allied Trades Federation, but it is bitterly opposed, for whatever reasons, by the National Farmers Federation. Its concerns have been known for some time and it has pursued its objections to the tally system in various places. For instance, it pursued them in the Industries Assistance Commission's inquiry into the abattoir and meat processing industry. The IAC, looking into that system and into aspects such as whether the tally system has resulted in reduced productivity compared to some other system, concluded in its report that the tally system as such does not impose a specific cost disability in these regards.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not an expert on the tally system and I simply say that inquiries have been held which have indicated that it is not disadvantageous to productivity in the industry, and that has been supported by the Meat and Allied Trades Federation. Nevertheless, it remains the case that the National Farmers Federation is seeking to destroy it, and Mudginberri is the perfect case to try to pursue that ambition. The Mudginberri dispute became the focus of the latest element of this struggle because of the decision of the Commission resulting from circumstances, which I think were accurately described by the shadow Minister, that led to the establishment of the award in April of this year to allow the contract system in the new award where it was agreed by a majority of employees or their nominated representative. The phrase `or their nominated representatives' meant that the union did not necessarily have to be involved. All employees at Mudginberri were non-union, either because they had never been members or because they had been expelled from the union. So they agreed with the employer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say that again, Ralph, we want to hear it again.

—That is all right. The honourable member said it and I agree that that is what happened. They agreed with the employer on the contract system without the involvement of the union. The union concern in relation to that is twofold, and I think that should be on the table. Firstly, the application of the contract system in the award is, as they see it, the thin edge of the wedge in the destruction of the tally system. Secondly, it also has some implications for the role of trade unions in the future, and that brings in other wider trade union concerns, including those of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and probably explains why the ACTU is strongly in support of the AMIEU in this dispute; that is, if employees can perform the kinds of actions which they are able to under this award then the role of trade unions, as the representatives of employees under the system, is undermined. Of course, the system is built on the ability of trade unions to represent employees in that industry. It is seen that this could cause substantial damage to the role of the trade unions as representatives of their members who are employees. Those are legitimate concerns. One can argue about the rights and wrongs of them but one cannot argue about the right of trade unions to have legitimate concerns about both those matters-about the basic role of trade unions and also about the basic system of payment which applies in the industry, which is clearly under threat, and publicly so, from the National Farmers Federation and which they see as being at risk by this decision. None of that excuses the taking of direct action to try to change that award.

SPEECH.PARA: The use of section 45D by the employers in seeking to resolve this dispute is, as I have said, totally counter-productive. Already fines of $44,000 have been applied, damages of some $2m are being sought, other costs have been taken from the union, and funds of over $2m have been frozen by sequestration orders. The fact remains that the use of section 45D has not resolved this dispute. It is absolutely pointless members opposite standing up here and saying `We have to defend the right of people to take action under the law', if that does not resolve the dispute. This Government has been trying to get the dispute into a situation where it can be resolved-that is the important point-and to get the pickets lifted so that the abattoir can operate normally and fulfil its export contracts. That is the kind of thing that needs to be done and it is not being achieved by using section 45D. That has led to national stoppages by members of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia and other maritime unions. If further action under section 45D is taken it is likely we will see further stoppages of that kind. If we want a national industrial conflagration we should continue to go down this path. That is obviously the desire of the Opposition, but it will not assist in a resolution of this dispute and it will not assist in achieving better industrial relations in this country.

We have sought to get the parties to discuss these matters. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) called a conference. It was not attended by the employer parties, who said that the matters were subjudice. That is one of the most ludicrous statements I have ever heard. Instead, it sent an extraordinary list of demands.

The fact is that this matter will be resolved only before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in an industrial sphere. I am pleased to see that today the AMIEU has finally agreed to take an application back to the Arbitration Commission and to try to resolve this in the only forum where it can be resolved. Let me say this in conclusion: If this is an example of what deregulation of the industry is going to bring, it will be great when we have the Opposition supplying hundreds of Mudginberris and fomenting industrial chaos as a result!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon P.A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has just told us to knuckle under to the unions when they do not like the law. That is his approach and their approach, but Jay Pendarvis and Joy, his wife, and their employees are in the vanguard of a new approach to industrial relations, one which is totally foreign to the Hawke Government. It is based on the belief that both employees and employers can benefit more by getting together and determining their own style of operation, their own work practices and their own wages and conditions directly than they can in any other way. The Government and the trade union movement, highly conservative and resistant to change, are very fond of predicting death, doom and disaster for employees who engage in direct negotiations with the employers on such matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the situation at Mudginberri. By bypassing the union, meat workers can earn up to double what they can earn under the union preferred tally system. What does the union movement offer the Mudginberri meat workers? It offers lower wages. There is a better way to conduct industrial relations, although the Hawke Government and the union movement refuse to acknowledge it. At Mudginberri abattoir they are fighting to protect a better way in industrial relations from the union reactionaries who see themselves becoming redundant as a result.

The events at the Mudginberri abattoir are no less than a test of the right of indivuduals in Australia to work together without the interference of big unionism and big government. Jay and Joy Pendarvis, the abattoir operators, are not big business with enormous resources and financial backing to take on the pigheaded and illegal victimisation of out-of-control unionism; nor are their workers strike breakers or scabs taking work from others or assisting bosses to take the bread out of the mouths of their fellow men and women. Jay and Joy Pendarvis are a couple of battlers in a remote bush abattoir trying to make a living for themselves in a tough industry. Their workers are a bunch of ordinary men and women sick and tired of being told how they may work, where they may work and under what arrangements by a union which is out of step with their aspirations. The Pendarvises have gone through the proper processes to reach agreement with their workers for the best deal for employers and employees and they have run slap bang into a vested interest union movement running scared at the very prospect of that arrangement, of being left out in the cold and of being irrelevant, because this union survives, thrives even, on ensuring that no one reaches agreement without its seal of approval.

Much is being said by ordinary men and women in Australia about uncontrolled union power today and apparent control of government by big unionism. At Mudginberri is the proof of the sad state of affairs we have reached-a situation in which small business people, just trying to make an honest buck, have their livelihood threatened and their hopes dashed by the irresponsible and illegal actions of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union determined to prevent at all costs harmony and accord between employer and employee.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), when it suits him, makes much of harmony and accord and of, as he says, `bringing Australia together'. But the events at Mudginberri demonstrate that that is no more than empty talk: Harmony and accord, but only if it does not undermine the strength of the big militant unions in Australia; harmony and accord-as long as it does not offend the career unionists who dominate our news each day telling other Australians and the Australian Government which way they may go. Harmony and accord-but at what price? It is too high a price. It is at the cost of the individual Australian, the ordinary consumer, the small business proprietor who wants to act within the law, to run his own business and to mind his own business. This Government and its Minister are covertly supporting the illegal actions of the AMIEU by refusing to ensure that Commonwealth meat inspectors cross illegal picket lines and do their job. Under the feeble pretence of acting to prevent an escalation of the dispute the Minister and this Government refuse to direct the men to take the right and proper action, namely, to authorise experienced Northern Territory Government veterinary officers to do the job the Minister cannot or will not get his own meat inspectors to do. So this Government is effectively providing the union with its strongest weapon-the ability to prevent the Mudginberri meat works from fulfilling its export orders.

This Government is clearly determined to send Jay and Joy Pendarvis broke. Small business people around Australia are drawing their own conclusions. Without the covert support-the conniving, to use the Minister's term-of this Government, the AMIEU's disruptive action would have absolutely no effect on the operation of the meat works. At the feet of this Government, therefore, must lie the main blame for the continuation and any nationwide escalation of this dispute. We can be quite sure of that.

The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) can say that he has ordered Commonwealth meat inspectors to cross the picket lines and that they have refused, but he knows full well that with the stroke of a pen he could authorise highly qualified and well-experienced Northern Territory Government veterinarians to inspect meat for export as well as for domestic sales, as they are already doing, and in a moment allow Mudginberri to fulfil its export orders, render the picket line ineffective and, to all intents and purposes, end the dispute. He knows that, but he dodges his responsibility; he allows illegal activity to prosper.

If the people of Australia want evidence of this Government's underhand dealings with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the AMIEU they only have to look at the deliberate and extraordinary breach of faith by the Prime Minister in his dealings with the National Farmers Federation and Pendarvis. On Monday of last week the National Farmers Federation handed over, in confidence, a without-prejudice submission detailing its position. Last Friday, after a meeting with the ACTU the AMIEU released the same document publicly. There is only one way in which that document could have got into the hands of the AMIEU-through the hand of the Prime Minister of Australia.

The complicity and duplicity of this Prime Minister, dominated as he is by the interests and officials of the ACTU, have been shown up again and again during this dispute. It seems that the Prime Minister is unable to remember that he is no longer ACTU President. One might have thought that, as Prime Minister of this country, he had undertaken some responsibility to uphold the findings of national institutions such as the Commonwealth's own courts and the awards of the Arbitration Commission, but here we find him undermining their awards and findings and saying in effect that he did not have to attach any importance to their findings, a suggestion which one might expect from the President of the ACTU but not, one would hope, from the Prime Minister.

Let us look at the record of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations who last night appeared on national television, deliberately misleading the public by saying that the court had vindicated the Government's action in this dispute. What an untruth! The court decision, which is being appealed, upheld only the discretion of Government to send in its meat inspectors or not. In no way did it endorse the actions taken or, more importantly, not taken. By publicly stating in Brisbane that `the use of section 45D was entirely unhelpful', the Minister betrayed his prejudice and complicity with the unions in this dispute.

Australians know full well today where this Government's loyalties lie-with collectivism disguised as consensus, with regimentation disguised as accord and with power of vested interests to subjugate, to frustrate and to impoverish the individuality of all independent Australian men and women. I am proud that this battle is being fought and will be won in the part of Australia that I represent in this House because these two Territorians and their employees will not knuckle under to rampant unionism. I say to Jay and Joy Pendarvis, from the vast majority of their fellow Australians: `For Australia's sake, for all our sakes, hang in there'.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill-by leave-presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill currently before the House is an historic piece of legislation. It represents a major departure from the normal processes for dealing with industrial relations problems in this country. Its objective is to provide machinery for the cancellation of the registration of the Builders Labourers Federation under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act or to provide for the effective equivalent of such deregistration in parts of Australia. Such action cannot be taken lightly. However, we have come to a point where the actions of the BLF are, in our opinion-and, we would believe, in the opinion of the community as a whole-totally unacceptable.

Despite being given many opportunities to do so, the BLF has shown, time and time again, that it is not willing to adhere to the established industrial relations processes. Indeed, it has treated those processes with absolute contempt. In so doing, the Government believes that the BLF has, on numerous occasions, breached undertakings to the Federal Court of Australia, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the Industrial Registrar, the Commonwealth Government, building industry employers, and even the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It is now patently clear that the BLF leadership is utterly untrustworthy and that it regards undertakings and agreements as mere stratagems to achieve a momentary advantage which can then be disregarded at will. Furthermore, its unprincipled, indeed outrageous, mode of operation has created havoc in the building industry, thereby causing extraordinary delays in building programs and crippling increases in costs. Its use of tactics such as breaking concrete pours, reckless application of work bans, resort to walk-offs or `homers', and claims for payment for time on strike, has made industrial relation in the industry a nightmare. Its resort to industrial blackmail, thuggery, violence and intimidation has added a further ugly dimension to its activities. Such behaviour cannot be tolerated and has resulted in the virtual alienation of the union from the rest of the trade union movement in some parts of the nation.

The building and construction industry occupies a vital role in the Australian economy. The Government has deliberately encouraged the industry as a major force in renewed economic growth since 1983 and activity is expected to continue to grow strongly in 1985-86. The continuation of that expansion and its contribution to the nation's economic prosperity has, however, been put at risk by the industrial disruption caused by the BLF. The Federation has around 35,000 members in non-residential construction, with almost 70 per cent of them employed in the industry in New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory. It has been the actions of the Federation in these areas which have been most disruptive and which have led to the legislation now before the House. The Federation's members are on site at the beginning and the end of projects and are involved in key activities in the course of a job, including steel fixing, concreting, scaffolding, crane driving, dogging and general trades assistance. This central position has been used ruthlessly by the BLF. Tactics such as bans on strategic equipment and parts of jobs, broken concrete pours, bans on truck deliveries and unloading and on overtime have been deployed with the objective of `the most harm to the boss, the least harm to ourselves'-to quote the New South Wales State Secretary of the Federation.

The BLF has become expert at exploiting the vulnerability of the construction process to press its demands. It has fully exploited the fact that once a project is under way, very often the cheapest alternative for an employer is to succumb to a demand rather than risk losses far in excess of the cost of an industrial settlement. This is not to excuse employers, however, some of whom have been far too willing in the past to accommodate the BLF. BLF tactics have also extended to action against parties not directly involved in the industry and even against other unions. Federation members have occupied buildings of insurance companies, private organisations and the Office of the Industrial Registrar and, at least on one occasion, premises of another union. The Federation has also shown disdain for the processes of conciliation and arbitration. It has continuously refused to abide by orders of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and consistently pursued claims outside the guidelines of the Commission. Further, it has broken numerous undertakings as to its conduct given to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the Industrial Registrar and the Federal Court of Australia.

These activities of the BLF are not a recent phenomenon-indeed, the Federation has been a major disruptive force in the industry throughout the past decade and a half. In 1974, the Federation was deregistered by the Industrial Court following four years of turmoil in the industry. In October 1976, the Federation was reregistered after giving specific undertakings to the Industrial Registrar to abide by decisions of the Commission and to participate fully in the prevention and settlement of disputes through conciliation and arbitration. Mr Gallagher, the Federal Secretary of the BLF, told the Commission in 1976:

I can further submit that the Commission can properly and confidently assume that the policy of this Federation is to resort to conciliation and arbitration through the Commission rather than direct action in breach of the Act or in breach of Awards of the Commission.
Mr Gallagher went on to say:

. . . the Union gives assurances that the employers can expect that acts of destruction of property, interruptions to concrete pours, interrupting the unloading of vehicles and the use of selective bans on vertical transport machinery, such as cranes, passengers/material hoists, which would inhibit the work of builders' labourers and of tradesmen will be forgone.

The record shows that from this time the union has had scant regard to these undertakings. It has, on a multitude of occasions, engaged in the kind of conduct it repudiated before the court, and its industrial record contains numerous examples of harmful demarcation disputes, broken concrete pours, violent conflicts with police and fellow unionists and disruptive campaigns over non-industrial issues.

The activities of the union over the period were well summarised in the 1982 report of the Winneke Royal Commission into the Activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation:

These tactics find no support or condonation in any industrial legislation in this country. The conduct not only exceeds the bounds of industrial propriety but, in many instances, plainly transgresses the Criminal Law . . . The result has been to place the BLF in a unique position-a position of being above the law.

In March 1983 when this Government took office, we were confronted by major difficulties in the industry. Industrial relations were at an extremely low ebb with widespread disputation revolving around award renegotiations involving all unions and the ongoing proceedings for deregistration of the BLF initiated by the previous Government in 1981. It was clear that those deregistration proceedings-initiated by the current leader of the opposition (Mr Peacock)-had little chance of achieving a lasting improvement in the industry. They were strongly opposed by the whole union movement, which would have backed up the BLF if it had been eventually deregistered. Despite the fact that the proceedings had already been under way for two years, there was every chance they could have meandered on for a number of years. Moreover, the proceedings had been initiated with absolutely no consultation with industry employers who were reluctantly dragged into the case. The general feeling amongst employers at the time was that they had been put into a no win situation by the Government of the day.

This Government adopted a strategy in 1983 and consistently through the next two years that the problems of the industry could best be solved through consultation and co-operation, leading to a negotiated settlement involving all parties, backed up by the Government. However, if this approach failed, the Government was prepared to take strong and effective action to achieve stability. In April 1983, the Government established the National Building and Construction Industry Conference under an independent Chairman to look at establishing the basis for a withdrawal of deregistration proceedings and so facilitate the establishment of an industry agreement. Building employers, unions, the Federal Government and the ACTU were represented at the Conference. In May 1983, agreement was reached, including a moratorium on further industrial action, as a basis for adjournment of the deregistration proceedings. As part of this agreement, the BLF reaffirmed, in detail, the undertakings it gave on reregistration in 1976. In the months that followed, negotiations between the parties continued, resulting in the building industry agreement.

The agreement provided, in return for superannuation, the most comprehensive package ever agreed upon in the industry to address the major industrial problems which had bedevilled the industry over a long period. Specific procedures were laid down to handle disputes including a seven-day cooling-off period. Practices such as claims for payment for time on strike, cash in hand, pyramid subcontracting, contrived safety issues, no-ticket no-start and demarcation disputes were specifically addressed in the agreement. There was also an agreement on no extra claims. It was hoped that, with the support of employers and all unions, the agreement would lay the foundation for a long period of stable industrial relations.

At the same time as the industry agreement was being developed, negotiations continued to seek a satisfactory basis for resolution of the deregistration proceedings, and in December 1983 the Government agreed to accept undertakings given by the BLF as the basis for withdrawing from the proceedings. Central to the Government's decision was the position taken by the ACTU, which supported the BLF's commitment and resolved to take all reasonable steps to ensure its observance by the union.

The BLF undertook to recognise its responsibilities as a registered organisation to work within the provisions and spirit of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and the national wage principles, and to utilise the means provided by the Act for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes. Earlier, in October 1983, the BLF had given a no extra claims commitment as required under the national wage principles. Again, only a few months passed before the BLF repudiated these commitments. During February 1984, the BLF embarked on a widespread and particularly disruptive campaign for a $9 pay claim rather than participating with other unions in negotiations for a superannuation scheme. Eventually, combined pressure from the Government, the ACTU and other unions convinced the BLF to drop its claim.

During the first half of 1984, the employer applicants were still pursuing deregistration. However, many employers recognised the problems associated with that course, especially when the necessary circumstances for it to be effective did not exist. In June 1984, the employers withdrew from the proceedings on the basis of a commitment by the Government to take effective action against the BLF if it failed to adhere to the industry agreement.

No sooner had the deregistration been terminated, however, than the BLF launched a widespread campaign seeking superannuation outside the building industry agreement. Although other unions had signed the agreement the BLF, which had been fully involved in negotiations leading to the agreement, broke away, refused to sign the agreement, and sought superannuation through an extremely disruptive industrial campaign. Further industrial action was taken in relation to charges against Mr Gallagher arising out of the Winneke Royal Commission.

Matters came to a head in September 1984 with vast sections of the industry in all States affected by the campaign. Again the BLF practised its typical style of brinkmanship and, when confronted with a preparedness by the Government to take strong action, the BLF sought a last minute tactical retreat and finally signed the agreement. However, the BLF's intentions of adhering to the terms of the agreement were soon in question. At the same time as it was signing the agreement, the BLF continued industrial actions over claims for strike pay and continued employment for its members at the Sydney Police Centre as well as in pursuit of shorter hours on shopping centre sites.

On 12 October 1984, building unions in Sydney met at a large combined meeting and condemned BLF's conduct at the Police Centre and alleged that 14 BLF members at the site had been involved in violence, threats and intimidation against fellow workers and their families. Calls by the ACTU executive and the Commission for an end to all BLF action over the site were ignored. Over 2,000 workers were stood down in New South Wales alone, with major sites all over the rest of the country also being affected. This action led to the decision by the New South Wales Government to deregister the BLF from the State's industrial jurisdiction. It was only at the end of February that bans were eventually lifted with a commitment by the BLF not to pursue claims for lost time-a commitment that was later ignored as other sites were banned in pursuit of such payment.

Meanwhile the BLF pursued its national campaign for a 36-hour week on shopping centres with a large number of projects in most States being forced to the point of closure. These claims were in clear breach of both the national wage principles and the building industry agreement. Furthermore, numerous bans and stoppages were imposed in all States in protest at the conviction and gaoling of Mr Gallagher.

The union's industrial action was only dropped in July when the resolve of Federal and State governments to act became obvious. The Victorian Government decided at this stage to legislate to deregister the BLF from its industrial jurisdiction.

Mr Deputy Speaker, it is abundantly clear in these circumstances that there is absolutely no course open to the Government than to introduce this legislation now before the House. The time has passed for yet another `last chance'. Since March 1983, the Government has explored every constructive option for achieving a resolution through the normal industrial processes to the problems posed for the industry by the BLF's behaviour. And yet these opportunities have invariably not been accepted by the BLF.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I now turn to the detailed provisions of the Bill. The Bill provides for two steps. First, a hearing is to take place before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission so that it can be independently determined whether the Federation has engaged in certain forms of serious industrial misconduct. Secondly, where the Commission so finds, the Minister will be able to take action against the Federation to exclude it from the Federal conciliation and arbitration system altogether, or limit its capacity to operate within the system. I should stress that the measures proposed by the Government against the Federation are being introduced because the Government believes that the Federation's conduct amounts to repudiation of the federal system for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes and of its responsibilities as a federally registered organisation of employees, as well as being utterly disruptive to industrial peace.

In the Government's view, the action which is contemplated in this legislation is so serious that it is essential that there be impartial consideration by an independent tribunal of the Federation's conduct. This will occur against specific criteria which are appropriate tests of whether the Federation has behaved responsibly as an organisation registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act in a way which is consistent with the objectives of our industrial relations system. Clause 4 therefore provides that where, on an application by the Minister, a Full Bench of the Commission is satisfied that the Federation has engaged in certain actions, the Commission is to declare in writing that it is so satisfied.

The first of the criteria in clause 4 concerns the Federation's record of compliance with its undertakings and agreements. The Commission will be able to consider whether the Federation has, by engaging in industrial action or by making claims supported by industrial action, contravened or acted inconsistently with the intent of agreements and undertakings to which it is a party. These include the building industry agreement which I referred to earlier, as well as the Federation's various undertakings to the Commission, the Registrar or the Federal Court of Australia. Undertakings given by the Federation to a party to a proceeding in which the Federation was involved before any of these tribunals are also included. And that, of course, includes its undertakings to the Government and to the employers given before the Federal Court in 1983 and 1984.

The agreements which the Federation has entered into and the undertakings it has given are all fundamental to its participation in the conciliation and arbitration system. As I have said, the Government, employers and many unions see those agreements and undertakings as meaning little to the Federation and the Commission will have the opportunity to determine whether that is so.

Provision is also made in clause 4 for an examination of whether the Federation has engaged in conduct which has seriously hindered or prevented the achievement of an object of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904, or whether the conduct of the Federation has been inimical to the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by conciliation and arbitration. The Federation will be given the opportunity of presenting argument on its conduct. This is provided for in clause 6.

For the purposes of clause 4, the Federation is made responsible for any industrial action or conduct by its members if it instigated or encouraged such conduct or action, or the Federation does not prove that it took all reasonable steps to prevent it. Once the Commission has made a declaration, the Bill provides for alternative courses of action against the Federation.

Clause 5 provides for the Minister to order the cancellation of the Federation's registration. This would mean that any award applying to the Federation or to its members would cease to have any force or effect in relation to them.

After its deregistration, the Federation would, under clause 7, be denied the capacity to be a party to any proceedings before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the Commission would not be able to deal with any industrial disputes to the extent that they involved members of the Federation. Before the Federation could be reregistered, the Minister may, under clause 5, specify conditions with which the Federation must comply.

There are alternatives to ordering the cancellation of the Federation's registration. The Minister may under clause 5 terminate or suspend the Federation's rights, privileges or capacities, or those of its members, under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act or under the rules of the Federation.

Under clause 8, the Minister may make orders so that the Federation ceases, while it remains registered, to be able to have coverage of employees engaged in work coming within the Federation's rules in parts of Australia specified by the Minister. Clause 8 also provides that, upon the making of such an order, the Federation is no longer able, for the purposes of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, to make any claims for or on behalf of any persons or to represent any members in the area specified in the order. The making of such an order will mean that the Federation cannot seek new awards or recruit members in relation to work in the relevant area. As to existing awards, clause 8 provides that any award applying to the Federation or its members ceases to have effect in relation to them unless, within 28 days of the making of the Minister's order, the Commission varies the awards so that they do not apply to the Federation or its members in the area specified in the order.

Clause 8 therefore permits a selective approach to be used in relation to the Federation. It will permit the Government to take action against the most disruptive sections of the BLF while allowing the more acceptable section to remain within the federal system. At this stage, this is the approach which the Government proposes to adopt. The action to be taken under this approach will, together with appropriate supplementary action under clause 5 in relation to the rights, privileges and capacities of the Federation, mean that consequences similar to those resulting from deregistration can apply, if necessary, to the recalcitrant elements of the union.

Whether the Federation has its registration cancelled or selective action is taken in relation to its representative rights, the Minister is able, by virtue of clause 9, to allocate by way of a declaration to any other federally registered unions coverage of work in an industry in respect of which the Federaton is or has been registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The relevant union would be required to consent to the Minister taking this action. Such action may be taken in relation to a particular part of Australia and may involve different kinds of work and different unions. This will enable the continued effective representation for the purposes of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act of persons who would otherwise have been eligible for membership of the Federation where it is deregistered or has its representative rights removed.

The Bill also permits the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to allocate Federation work coverage to other federally registered unions. The Commission may consider such allocation of work coverage where an application is made by a federally registered union or by the Minister. The Commission will have to be satisfied that it is desirable for the union concerned to have that work coverage allocated to it so that the objects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act are achieved and the employees concerned will be effectively represented for the purposes of the Act. The Act will cease to be in force by virtue of clause 15 on a day to be fixed by Proclamation.

This Bill represents positive action by the Government towards securing improved industrial relations in the industry. The Government expects support from the industry to ensure the success of measures taken under it. In conjunction with the measures in the Bill, employers will be expected to adopt a code of industrial behaviour to rid the industry of the improper practices being fostered by the BLF. Although such a code will require no more than stringent adherence to awards, agreements and normal industrial practices, its implementation would be a major step towards improved industrial relations in the industry. The Government is also giving consideration to non-legislative measures designed to ensure that contractors on government projects adhere to government industrial relations policies. We will be approaching State and local governments to adopt similar measures.

It is essential that this legislation be enacted with the utmost expedition. The Government will be looking to the co-operation of all parties to ensure its rapid progress through the Parliament. As soon as the legislation is passed, I will be applying to the Commission for the declaration which is required under the Bill before any action can be taken against the BLF. The Bill provides for an expeditious hearing before the Commission and the Government will take every feasible step to ensure that this is the case. I commend the Bill to the House.
